comments.commentBody: thank you and godspeed. <3

I think the value of a man goes well beyond what you expect him to do as a father and husband....what has he done to make the world a better place?  Who has he helped that didn't ask for his (or anyone's help?).  What has he given back to society?  My own father was every bit in love with my mom (and vice versa) as the author and her husband.  He was as good a father as a son could ask for-and my sister would agree.   But my Dad also served in the Army, he served his community, and he served his faith.  He tirelessly contributed to the poor.  I remember at every semester's end when he would take our textbooks and novels that we were required to purchase and just drive to a very poor neighborhood and knock on doors until he found someone whose family could use them.  He was an amazing son to my Grandmother, a better sibling his brothers and sisters could not have asked for: he was a man of rare integrity.  And he was amazingly good looking through his late 70's-and beyond.  Sorry ladies, he passed away six years after the love of his life.
Oh, get over yourself. You know nothing about her husband.

Why do you have this preconception that (1) Amy 's Jason is ONLY a loving husband and a devoted father, but not anything else for the wider society? (2) the female readers of this essay and posts would want to have anything to do with your father? (from your last sentence).
In case of (1) Amy has every right to list up whatever qualities of her love of life possesses, and leave other qualities he has not mentioned specifically. Right now for her what matters the most about her loving husband are those most intimate qualities. That does not mean that those are the SUM of Jason.
In case of (2) your FATHER must have been a great person overall - I would not dare to say otherwise about a beloved parent. My only problem is how in the world such a kind person ' s own flesh and blood turned out to be an insensitive person like you. So even if he were here, after getting to know his son, the ladies may not want to have anything to do with him.
How very sweet.  You will live in my memory!
Am I dead inside because this made me feel nothing? It just seemed schmaltzy.

Why would you say this? If it left you feeling dead,maybe it's because you have never experienced a love like hers. If you thought it was anything but what it is meant to be,a love letter to her husband,why bother saying anything negative?
Expect to be told you don't like puppies and kittens either.

Your story reminds us all to appreciate the loved ones around us and will stay in my heart and well as those who read this. Amy and Jason  are leaving a legacy with 3 children and all that got to be part of your relationship. Super hugs to you as you are surrounded by those you love.

Doc.... 'The Pope' is also a human being who obviously cares quite a bit about humanity.

Your categorical dismissal of him is quite telling.

This reminds me of my husband's late wife. I got a wonderful man who had been married for 25 years. Breast cancer took her. She had taught him much and I got man, well broken in--if you will. He knew not to sweet the small stuff, how to make a woman happy, how to be a partner. She was part of a writing group as the disease was taking her. One of the last things she wrote was, "I don't know what I fear most, that he will love again or the sadness that he will never love again". I was lucky that she released him. She was a wonderful woman. Kevin is a wonderful man.

Most Republicans don't seem to find Russian intervention in our election troubling. As serious and ominous as Russia's actions are, the Republican indifference about it seems far worse. I don't see how we put our country back together if they continue with their current attitude.
Most Republicans are just fine with having their drinking water polluted.  These aren't the sharpest tools in the shed.

For some, because it's not all of them, it seems more like blatant disregard for the impact that "now" actions and decisions will have on our future - e.g., a president with close advisers who have even less political experience than he, the disregard for the separation of personal business from the office of the presidency, family members sucking us dry as they conduct their personal business, the selection of people with shameful stains on their integrity and knowledge, including one with an openly dark and insanity driven agenda- a president who doesn't understand that every "show" is not a good show, that his words are heard by the rest of us and the world not just those who praise him, that appearances and perceptions matter and do inspire related actions - actions by Americans (divisions and protests), but also others around the world. He represents the whole of our country not just those who fawn after him. When he behaves like a petulant child, like a clown, we see but so do the world's leaders -those who mean us no good. Appearances and perceptions of our president, of our country matter - they inspire actions. And one overly coached, practiced and memorized speech doesn't begin to persuade at thinking public. It only highlights how inept and inappropriate all that has gone before really is.

Amy,

Your story is profoundly similar to mine and my husband's and it touched me. I lost my husband suddenly last year, but he passed doing what he loved in the hills and forest instead of behind a desk or in a car. He was my best friend and I miss him terribly. He always got flowers just because, never lost the child in him and helped me find mine again, very much enjoyed music and his sound system. I have to agree the Snell's have an amazing sound.

We went on safari's, but not to Africa. Our's were taking off on a Saturday taking turns saying "turn right" or "turn left". He never brought be gumballs, but we have a wonderful marble collection and he would bring me animal crackers in the little box.

We did not go out much because...well...truthfully, we enjoyed cooking at home together, working our gardens, and sitting on the deck till late night watching the sunset and star shows.

Our live together for 15 years was wonderful and I appreciate every moment for the blessing it was. I am sure you feel the same, as does Jason.

Oh,...we met on eBay..lol....not the most romantic start..but he he totally wooed me for six months till I gave in and come to see him in New Hampshire from Mississippi. I moved up 10 days later and the story began.

I will keep you all in my thoughts and prayers and if Jason is ever in New Hampshire he is more than welcome for a good dinner and someone to talk to. I am an excellent listener.

Love and blessings,
Angela (angle)
Before my husband of 28 years died of ALS he made me promise to live my life robustly.  Amy's gift is the same.  Good for her.  Good for my husband.  Their love transcends time and space.
Blessings to you, Lisa.

Amy,

Thank you for sharing your beautifully written letter. I'll keep you in my prayers. May god continue to bless you and your family.

Paul

Amy, this is one of the most beautiful pieces I've ever read. Wishing you freedom from pain, and as many moments as possible to look into your husband's eyes and hold his hand. May God be with you both. (I bought Little Hoot to read to my daughter when she was tinier and we both loved the story of the adorable owl who desperately wanted to go to bed, but his parents wouldn't let him.)
Just like Mother, when she was dying. She gave my brother and me guidance about how we were to guide my Father. He had friends, but never could match those 40 years with another.
Oh please totally unfounded
I love, love your answer.  Ben.  Great.
A potent third party might help, if only to wander around, by day, with a lantern, looking for an honest person.

I for one am going to sit back and enjoy the spectacle that is going to unfold.  It could very well be true that the contacts were routine, but there is too much of an appearance of suspicious (perhaps treasonous) behavior for this thing to get turned off by Trump's bluster.  An immense fly wheel is beginning to rotate and  obstruction will do nothing but aggravate the situation.  Patriots and political opponents are doing their jobs when they investigate, get used to it - this is far more disturbing and substantive than Hillary's emails or Bengazi.

Has she lied about the meeting in the photo? Where is the occasion of the photo? Who else was there? Who took the photo?
This tweet smacks of a childish distraction as a come back to an unacceptable situation which is being properly drilled down until the truth emerges. Trump is backed against the wall and this is all he's got?

<< rolls eyes >>

You do know that the USSR is gone for over 25 years now? and that THE RUSSIAN REPUBLIC does not fly the hammer & sickle flag of the USSR?

Even if the contacts were benign and innocent, the fact that Trump and his people tried to hide them makes it look as if they have something to hide, as does the reluctance of Republicans to start an independent investigation. If they have nothing to hide, they have nothing to fear from the truth, and in fact it would be in their own interests to cooperate with an independent investigation in order to put the suspicions to rest.

Of course, maybe the Republicans are simply afraid that the Democrats will use their own tactics against them. After all, they successfully used incessant investigations of Hillary Clinton to discredit her, despite not finding anything particularly damning, and there are still people who believe that Barack Obama was not born in the United States despite all evidence to the contrary. You reap what you sow, and if your tactics are successful against your opponents, you can't really fault them for using them against you.

Rachel Maddow reported on the fact that Dmitry Rybolovlev (the Russian Fertilizer King) flew into the same airport as Donald Trump numerous times during the campaign for no apparent reason. Mr. Rybolovlev owns part of the Bank of Cyprus which was funneling dirty money from Deutsche Bank in Germany. It appears that DJT received around a billion dollars of this money. See the Palmer Report.

https://www.palmerreport.com/news/dmitry-rybolovlev-who-keeps-flying-in-...

But the President IS NOT elected by a popular vote. Everyone who has read the Constitution knows this. Why don't YOU know this?

GW Bush did not win the popular vote, and he only won the EC with ONE MEASLY VOTE -- I think this is the lowest win in history. He had no mandate. Yet he was able to not only get re-elected, but lead us into two long-lasting wars.

You seem to think that if a President does not get the popular vote, he is not allowed to have full Presidential powers....is just a figurehead. That is factually untrue.
Can we find out how often Democratic politicians met with the Russians to put this in context?

See, now, I'm neutral. I didn't vote for Clinton or Trump. I'm as interested as anyone else for an investigation, but my understanding was that the intelligent communities were already investigating it since the campaign. So, what's taking so long? Why is there not enough information yet to form conclusions? Or will we be tying up government and stagnating due to partisan politics for another administration?

Meanwhile Obama ruled the roost with executive orders that provoked anger, while Repubs and Dems in Congress brought governing to a halt. And now we have a new administration and the same thing is happening. No governing. Just mud slinging. And the Democratic party can not pretend to not be 1000% motivated in removing Trump from office. Anyone that denies that is fooling no one. There is an organized attempt to overthrow the administration.

So I agree with dog secrets - both parties are not worth supporting. And just the fact that only 3 people up voted this comment, tells you all you need to know about the hypocrisy and denial of Democrats, who continue to suggest that only the Republicans are a problem. There is no impartiality or objectivity.
